On Monday 17 May 2004 09:15 pm, Eric Nickell wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "chbeer78" <Christian.beer@d...> wrote:
> > Up to my question: What is the best way to test units, that create
> > files (in my case they are PDF files).
> >
> > I see two oppinions for that (my case: PDFs) :
> >
> > 1) visual testing (no automation)
> >
> > 2) visual testing + file comparison (create a pdf that fits your needs
> > and check created files against that by file comparison; critical with
> > PDFs because two different PDF may look the same :-/ )
> >
> > What is your opinion about that? Or am I seeing something wrong? Or is
> > it impossible to JUnit-test file creation?

Are you creating the PDFs yourself or via a 3rd party library (eg. iText, Big 
Faceless)?

If the former, you really should have no problem in that you know what you are 
expecting at least in the way of bytes that get written.  So, test that.  
Refactoring to use streams would be a plus so that the tests don't actually 
write to disk.  I did this on a former project and it worked well.

If the latter, encapsulate (into another class) the logic that goes into 
determining what to write to the PDF and test that.  Leave the testing of 
produced PDF to customer tests (which may be nothing more than having a 
customer view some actual PDFs and say 'Yea' or 'Nay').  I did this on a 
former project as well and it suited our needs.
